skill.name: writing-tests
skill.description: Guidelines on writing tests for the backend
skill.summary: Guidelines on writing tests for the backend
skill.author: Crossbill-Highlights

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only a single SKILL.md file with textual guidelines for writing backend tests. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or external command execution. Pure prompt-based skill with zero attack surface.

content.value_statement: Writing tests for backend code requires careful organization to ensure maintainability and coverage. This skill provides guidelines for creating test suites that stay maintainable as codebases grow.
actual_capabilities: Provides guidelines for structuring backend test cases
Recommends using fixtures for common test data setup
Encourages keeping individual tests short and focused
limitations: Does not provide language-specific testing frameworks
Does not generate actual test code
Does not include integration testing patterns
Does not cover frontend testing approaches

use_cases.title: Organize test suites
use_cases.description: Structure backend tests for long-term maintainability using fixtures and helper functions

use_cases.title: Create test fixtures
use_cases.description: Set up reusable test data that can be shared across multiple test cases

use_cases.title: Learn test patterns
use_cases.description: Understand best practices for writing tests that the entire team can follow

prompt_templates.title: Basic test request
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a test for the user login function that verifies correct credentials work and incorrect credentials fail

prompt_templates.title: Test with fixtures
prompt_templates.prompt: Write tests for the order processing module using fixtures for common order states like pending, completed, and cancelled

prompt_templates.title: Parameterized tests
prompt_templates.prompt: Write parameterized tests for the validation function that checks multiple input types and edge cases

prompt_templates.title: Integration test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an integration test for the payment flow that tests the full sequence from checkout to confirmation

best_practices: Keep each test case focused on a single behavior or assertion
Use fixtures to setup common test data that multiple tests share
Extract repeated setup logic into reusable helper functions
anti_patterns: Writing long tests that try to verify multiple unrelated behaviors
Duplicating setup code across many test cases
Hardcoding test data directly in test functions instead of using fixtures

faq.question: Which testing frameworks are supported?
faq.answer: The guidelines are framework-agnostic and apply to pytest, unittest, Jest, and other testing libraries.

faq.question: How many assertions should each test have?
faq.answer: Keep tests focused on one behavior. One assertion per test is ideal but grouped assertions on one behavior are acceptable.

faq.question: Can these guidelines apply to frontend tests?
faq.answer: The guidelines focus on backend patterns. Frontend testing has additional considerations like UI state and component rendering.

faq.question: Is my test data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: No data is stored. The skill only provides guidelines for organizing and writing tests.

faq.question: How do I handle async test operations?
faq.answer: Use async test runners and fixtures. Ensure proper cleanup after async operations complete.

faq.question: How is this different from other test generators?
faq.answer: This skill provides guidelines rather than generating code. It focuses on test organization and maintainability patterns.
